title: Welcome To My Blog
text:
This is the first post in a Quarto blog. Welcome!

Since this post doesn’t specify an explicit image, the first image in the post will be used in the listing page of posts.

wages_clean <-
  wages %>%
  tidyr::drop_na(realrinc) 


# Set graph theme
theme_set(new = theme_classic())
#
wages_clean %>%
  gf_boxplot(realrinc ~ "Income") %>% # Dummy X-axis "variable"
  gf_labs(
    title = "Plot 1A: Income has a skewed distribution",
    subtitle = "Many outliers on the high side"
  )









# Set graph theme
theme_set(new = theme_classic())
#
wages_clean %>%
  gf_boxplot(gender ~realrinc ) %>%
  gf_labs(title = "Plot 2A: Income by Gender")









# Set graph theme
theme_set(new = theme_classic())
##
wages_clean %>%
  gf_boxplot(gender ~ log10(realrinc)) %>%
  gf_labs(title = "Plot 2B: Log(Income) by Gender")









# Set graph theme
theme_set(new = theme_classic())
#
wages_clean %>%
  gf_boxplot(wrkstat ~realrinc ) %>%
  gf_labs(title = "Plot 2A: Income by Work Status")









# Set graph theme
theme_set(new = theme_classic())
##
wages_clean %>%
  gf_boxplot(educcat ~ log10(realrinc)) %>%
  gf_labs(title = "Plot 2B: Log(Income) by Gender")

(`stat_boxplot()`).









Why use log income instead of income?(google search)
When dealing with income level or economic value, the numbers are generally large. The log has the effect of de-scaling effect of the large number for ease of handling. After the calculation or modeling is complete, the final result can be converted back to its original scale.

Why use log income instead of income?(google search)
When dealing with income level or economic value, the numbers are generally large. The log has the effect of de-scaling effect of the large number for ease of handling. After the calculation or modeling is complete, the final result can be converted back to its original scale.

I’m grouping the ‘math_anxiety_modified’ dataset by Primary Grade and calculating the average grade and count of entries in that group-

math_anxiety_modified %>%
  group_by(Grade="Primary") %>%
  summarize(average_Grade = mean(Grade), count = n())

  Grade   average_Grade count
  <chr>           <dbl> <int>
1 Primary            NA   599


I’m grouping the data by gender and calculating the average AMAS score for boys and girls. Boys have an average score of about 21.17 with 323 entries, while girls have an average score of about 22.93 with 276 entries.

math_anxiety_modified %>%
  group_by(Gender) %>%
  summarize(average_RCMAS = mean(RCMAS), count = n())

# A tibble: 2 × 3
  Gender average_RCMAS count
  <chr>          <dbl> <int>
1 Boy             18.1   323
2 Girl            20.6   276


I’m grouping the data by gender to find the average AMAS score. Boys have an average score of about 21.17 based on 323 entries, while girls have a higher average score of about 22.93 from 276 entries.

math_anxiety_modified %>%
  group_by(Gender) %>%
  summarize(average_AMAS = mean(AMAS), count = n())

# A tibble: 2 × 3
  Gender average_AMAS count
  <chr>         <dbl> <int>
1 Boy            21.2   323
2 Girl           22.9   276


Conclusion: These stats helped me see how boys and girls differed in math anxiety levels and how their scores changed within each group.
Can’t wait for tomorrow :D

I’m grouping the ‘math_anxiety_modified’ dataset by Primary Grade and calculating the average grade and count of entries in that group-

math_anxiety_modified %>%
  group_by(Grade="Primary") %>%
  summarize(average_Grade = mean(Grade), count = n())

! argument is not numeric or logical: returning NA

  Grade   average_Grade count
  <chr>           <dbl> <int>
1 Primary            NA   599


I’m grouping the data by gender and calculating the average AMAS score for boys and girls. Boys have an average score of about 21.17 with 323 entries, while girls have an average score of about 22.93 with 276 entries.

math_anxiety_modified %>%
  group_by(Gender) %>%
  summarize(average_RCMAS = mean(RCMAS), count = n())

# A tibble: 2 × 3
  Gender average_RCMAS count
  <chr>          <dbl> <int>
1 Boy             18.1   323
2 Girl            20.6   276


I’m grouping the data by gender to find the average AMAS score. Boys have an average score of about 21.17 based on 323 entries, while girls have a higher average score of about 22.93 from 276 entries.

math_anxiety_modified %>%
  group_by(Gender) %>%
  summarize(average_AMAS = mean(AMAS), count = n())

# A tibble: 2 × 3
  Gender average_AMAS count
  <chr>         <dbl> <int>
1 Boy            21.2   323
2 Girl           22.9   276


Conclusion: These stats helped me see how boys and girls differed in math anxiety levels and how their scores changed within each group.
Can’t wait for tomorrow :D

Replicating the graph.

# Creating a profit ratio column
movieprofits <- movieprofits %>%
  mutate(profit_ratio = as.numeric(profit_ratio) / as.numeric(production_budget))  # Replace with actual column names

# Grouping by genre and distributor to calculate median profit ratio
median_profit_data <- movieprofits %>%
  group_by(genre, distributor) %>%
  summarise(median_profit_ratio = median(profit_ratio, na.rm = TRUE)) %>%  # Calculate median
  ungroup()  # Ungroup after summarizing

`summarise()` has grouped output by 'genre'. You can override using the
`.groups` argument.

glimpse(median_profit_data)

Rows: 30
Columns: 3
$ genre               <chr> "Action", "Action", "Action", "Action", "Action", …
$ distributor         <chr> "20th Century Fox", "Other", "Paramount Pictures",…
$ median_profit_ratio <dbl> 4326662, 4289208, 3566068, 3356647, 3560683, 23373…





# Set graph theme
theme_set(theme_classic())

# Creating the plot using the summarized data
ggplot(median_profit_data, aes(x = median_profit_ratio, y = genre)) + geom_col() + facet_wrap(~ distributor, nrow = 2, scales = "free_x") +
  labs(title = "Profits Made by Film Distributors",
       subtitle = "Ratio of Profits to Budgets",
       x = "Median Profit Ratio",
       y = "Genre")

Replicating the graph.

# Creating a profit ratio column
movieprofits <- movieprofits %>%
  mutate(profit_ratio = as.numeric(profit_ratio) / as.numeric(production_budget))  # Replace with actual column names

# Grouping by genre and distributor to calculate median profit ratio
median_profit_data <- movieprofits %>%
  group_by(genre, distributor) %>%
  summarise(median_profit_ratio = median(profit_ratio, na.rm = TRUE)) %>%  # Calculate median
  ungroup()  # Ungroup after summarizing

`summarise()` has grouped output by 'genre'. You can override using the
`.groups` argument.

glimpse(median_profit_data)

# Set graph theme
theme_set(theme_classic())

# Creating the plot using the summarized data
ggplot(median_profit_data, aes(x = median_profit_ratio, y = genre)) + geom_col() + facet_wrap(~ distributor, nrow = 2, scales = "free_x") +
  labs(title = "Profits Made by Film Distributors",
       subtitle = "Ratio of Profits to Budgets",
       x = "Median Profit Ratio",
       y = "Genre")

## Convert `dow`, `local`, and `month` into ordered factors
taxi_modified <- taxi %>%
  mutate(
    dow = factor(dow,
      levels = c("Mon", "Tue", "Wed", "Thu", "Fri", "Sat", "Sun"),
      labels = c("Mon", "Tue", "Wed", "Thu", "Fri", "Sat", "Sun"),
      ordered = TRUE
    ),
    ##
    local = factor(local,
      levels = c("no", "yes"),
      labels = c("no", "yes"),
      ordered = TRUE
    ),
    ##
    month = factor(month,
      levels = c("Jan", "Feb", "Mar", "Apr"),
      labels = c("Jan", "Feb", "Mar", "Apr"),
      ordered = TRUE
    )
  )
taxi_modified %>% glimpse()

## Set graph theme
theme_set(new = theme_classic())
##theme_custom doesn't work for me:(


#the tilda symbol below '~' signifies that tip is on the x-axis. So basically tilda(~) to the left of anything means that variable is on the x-axis. So here, local is also on the x-axis, but as color.
#color = ~local only shows the outline, whereas, fill is used to color it inside as well
#two variable are used here, tip and local. local is married to color.
gf_bar(~tip, data = taxi_modified, fill = ~local,) %>%
  gf_labs(title = "Plot 1A: Counts of Tips")









## Set graph theme
theme_set(new = theme_classic())
##

#position ="stack" is default
gf_bar(~tip, data = taxi_modified, fill = ~local, position="dodge",) %>%
  gf_labs(title = "Plot 1A: Counts of Tips")









## Set graph theme
theme_set(new = theme_classic())
##

#Question-Do non-local people tip more than local people?

## Showing "per capita" percentages
## Better labelling of Y-axis
taxi_modified %>%
  gf_bar(~local,
    fill = ~tip,
    position = "fill"
  ) %>%
  gf_labs(
    title = "Plot 2D: Filled Bar Chart",
    subtitle = "Shows Per group differences in Proportions!"
  )









## Set graph theme
theme_set(new = theme_classic())
#

#Question-which company has the most non-tippers?
## Showing "per capita" percentages
## Better labelling of Y-axis
taxi_modified %>%
  gf_bar(~company, fill = ~tip, position = "fill") %>%
  gf_labs(
    title = "Plot 2D: Filled Bar Chart",
    subtitle = "Shows Per group differences in Proportions!"
  ) %>%
  gf_theme(theme(axis.text.x = element_text(size = 6, angle = 45, hjust = 1)))









## Set graph theme
theme_set(new = theme_classic())

#5pm is the busiest hour and 3pm the least.
##
gf_bar(~hour, fill = ~tip, data = taxi_modified) %>%
  gf_labs(title = "Plot B: Counts of Tips by Hour")









## Set graph theme
theme_set(new = theme_classic())

#5pm is the busiest hour and 3pm the least.
##
gf_bar(~hour, fill = ~tip, data = taxi_modified, position = "fill") %>%
  gf_labs(title = "Plot B: Counts of Tips by Hour")









##
## This may be too busy a graph...
gf_bar(~ dow | hour, fill = ~tip, data = taxi_modified, position = "fill") %>%
  gf_labs(
    title = "Plot F: Counts of Tips by Hour and Day of Week",
    subtitle = "Is this plot arrangement easy to grasp?"
  )









##
## This may be too busy a graph...
gf_bar(~hour, fill = ~tip, data = taxi_modified, position = "fill") %>%
  gf_labs(
    title = "Plot F: Counts of Tips by Hour and Day of Week",
    subtitle = "Is this plot arrangement easy to grasp?"
  )

## Convert `dow`, `local`, and `month` into ordered factors
taxi_modified <- taxi %>%
  mutate(
    dow = factor(dow,
      levels = c("Mon", "Tue", "Wed", "Thu", "Fri", "Sat", "Sun"),
      labels = c("Mon", "Tue", "Wed", "Thu", "Fri", "Sat", "Sun"),
      ordered = TRUE
    ),
    ##
    local = factor(local,
      levels = c("no", "yes"),
      labels = c("no", "yes"),
      ordered = TRUE
    ),
    ##
    month = factor(month,
      levels = c("Jan", "Feb", "Mar", "Apr"),
      labels = c("Jan", "Feb", "Mar", "Apr"),
      ordered = TRUE
    )
  )
taxi_modified %>% glimpse()

## Set graph theme
theme_set(new = theme_classic())
##theme_custom doesn't work for me:(


#the tilda symbol below '~' signifies that tip is on the x-axis. So basically tilda(~) to the left of anything means that variable is on the x-axis. So here, local is also on the x-axis, but as color.
#color = ~local only shows the outline, whereas, fill is used to color it inside as well
#two variable are used here, tip and local. local is married to color.
gf_bar(~tip, data = taxi_modified, fill = ~local,) %>%
  gf_labs(title = "Plot 1A: Counts of Tips")









## Set graph theme
theme_set(new = theme_classic())
##

#position ="stack" is default
gf_bar(~tip, data = taxi_modified, fill = ~local, position="dodge",) %>%
  gf_labs(title = "Plot 1A: Counts of Tips")









## Set graph theme
theme_set(new = theme_classic())
##

#Question-Do non-local people tip more than local people?

## Showing "per capita" percentages
## Better labelling of Y-axis
taxi_modified %>%
  gf_bar(~local,
    fill = ~tip,
    position = "fill"
  ) %>%
  gf_labs(
    title = "Plot 2D: Filled Bar Chart",
    subtitle = "Shows Per group differences in Proportions!"
  )









## Set graph theme
theme_set(new = theme_classic())

#Question-which company has the most non-tippers?

## Better labelling of Y-axis
taxi_modified %>%
  gf_bar(~company, fill = ~tip, position = "fill") %>%
  gf_labs(
    title = "Plot 2D: Filled Bar Chart",
    subtitle = "Shows Per group differences in Proportions!"
  ) %>%
  gf_theme(theme(axis.text.x = element_text(size = 6, angle = 45, hjust = 1)))









## Set graph theme
theme_set(new = theme_classic())

#5pm is the busiest hour and 3pm the least.

  gf_labs(title = "Plot B: Counts of Tips by Hour")

gf_bar(~hour, fill = ~tip, data = taxi_modified, position = "fill") %>%
  gf_labs(title = "Plot B: Counts of Tips by Hour")

gf_bar(~ dow | hour, fill = ~tip, data = taxi_modified, position = "fill") %>%
  gf_labs(
    title = "Plot F: Counts of Tips by Hour and Day of Week",
    subtitle = "Is this plot arrangement easy to grasp?"
  )

title: Day-6
text:
population - parameters
sample - statistics
sample mean and population mean
sample mean is equally likely to be on either side. (it is fair)
any mean can be positive or negative
whereas, sd(standard deviation0 can never be negative
the mean of the sample mean is the population mean
Bell curve
Should the conference interval be big or smaller? (answer is smaller) So we are sure -95 % , so we have to trust the sample mean
The lady who drank tea story - if those same tea-cups were reshuffled and given
rng - random number generation poisson distribution
Statistical Inference —> Samples, Populations, Statistics and Inference

# Plotting salaries and gender proportion in the workforce

  scale_size_area(max_size = 15) +
  theme(plot.title = element_text(hjust = 0.5), 
        panel.grid.major = element_blank(), 
        panel.grid.minor = element_blank()) + 
  scale_y_continuous(labels = scales::dollar_format())
